I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) aims to deepen the skills and 
capacity to plan and implement effective communications strategies in developing member 
countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The TA will develop and deliver 
communications capacity building activities for DMCs, primarily for planning and finance ministries 
and  related  agencies.  The  TA  will  promote  interactions  among  government  officials  and 
international experts to enable them to share lessons, knowledge, and experience related to 
communications in a range of contexts.  
 
2.  This  TA  aligns  with  Strategy  2030,  particularly  in  its  emphasis  on  major  global 
commitments, such as the Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Agreement on climate 
change.  It emphasizes ADB’s role as (a) a knowledge provider focused on practical solutions that 
fit local conditions, identify lessons, and replicate good practices across the region and beyond; 
and (b) a convener of partnerships to promote dialogue and collaboration among development 
partners and stakeholders such as the private sector, philanthropic organizations, academe, 
foundations, and aid and development agencies. Improved communications will contribute to 
achieving Strategy 2030’s goal of supporting DMC governments’ institutional capacity and ability 
to efficiently plan, design, and implement policies, programs, and projects to enable their delivery 
of country development plans and contribution to global commitments.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  A development challenge. DMC officials responsible for the communications function in 
their organizations lack the skills and capacity required to effectively meet rising demands for 
information and transparency, and to manage communications challenges that may adversely 
affect the planning and prioritizing, design and implementation of government policies, programs, 
or projects. There are at least two effects of this situation: (a) stakeholders lack information on 
government policies, programs, or projects that may lead to opposition, resulting in delay and/or 
additional costs during design and implementation and (b) government ministries or agencies are 
unable to effectively manage or respond to reputational risks that could reduce public trust in their 
ability to plan, design, and implement government policies, programs, or projects. The Report of 
the G20 Eminent Persons Group on Global Financial Governance called on international financial 
institutions “to put risk at the center” of their strategies, including building trust and transparency 
among different players.2 
 
4.  Rapidly evolving communications environment. The communications environment in 
DMCs is rapidly evolving as expanded digitization and internet access fuels content creation, 
feeds the 24-hour news cycle, and powers pervasive social media use and social networking. 
This  environment  changes  how  the  public  interacts  with  and  consumes  information  from 
governments and other sources, and how individuals perceive government decisions and actions. 
The rapidly evolving communications environment directly impacts the work of communications 
professionals  and demands  new  approaches  to achieve  the communications objectives of 
government ministries and agencies. Without having a broad set of skills and strategic planning 
capabilities to manage communications, DMC officials cannot effectively convey the development 
agenda needed to get buy-in for key government initiatives from the public. ADB’s prior technical 
assistance to support communications officials in DMCs identified the need to broaden their skills 
 
1 The TA first appeared in the Business Opportunities section of the ADB website on 10 December 2019. 
2 Global Financial Governance. 2018. Making the Global Financial System Work for All.

2 
and  strategic  communications  planning  and  execution  capability  to  effectively  manage 
communications across traditional, digital, and other channels to build awareness, understanding, 
and support for government policies, programs, and projects.3 
 
5.  Rising public expectations about transparency and participation. The growing ease 
of access to information, expansion of social media, and proliferation of information sources have 
increased  public  expectations  about  government  transparency  and  public  demand  for 
opportunities to participate in government decision-making and implementation. The development 
community has recognized the value of two-way communications systems that enable dialogue 
and allow communities to express their aspirations and concerns and participate in decisions 
concerning their development.4 DMC communicators must leverage new approaches, tools, and 
technologies to meet these demands. This will require increasingly sophisticated efforts to (a) 
establish communications objectives, (b) identify and understand the views of key stakeholders, 
(c) develop strategic messaging frameworks and content, (d) select appropriate channels and 
tools for information dissemination, and (e) execute communications plans. 
 
6.  Insufficient on-the-job training. Competition for limited resources within and among 
government agencies often limits learning opportunities for those responsible for communications 
functions. Learning to mainstream modern, cost-efficient, and context-appropriate tools and 
methods in communications planning and administration would greatly address this gap and more 
effectively convey messages to intended stakeholders. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: institutional capacity and transparency for the 
implementation of development policies and projects improved.5 The TA will have the following 
outcome: communications planning and implementation in participating DMCs improved.6 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Communications planning and implementation capacity strengthened. 
The TA will support at least 10 national capacity building activities, such as seminars, workshops, 
and training.  
  
9.  The course structure and training levels will be progressive, from basic to intermediate to 
advanced, over the TA period to develop a core of well-trained communications staff in target 
government ministries and agencies. Depending on the results of the training needs assessment 
for  each  DMC,  course  content  may  cover  any  combination  of  the  following:  (a)  strategic 
communications  principles  and  approaches;  (b)  stakeholder  identification;  (c)  message 
development; (d) campaign planning and management; (e) content development; (f) social media 
strategy, including applying digital, web, and mobile technologies; (g) media interaction; (h)

measurement and evaluation; and (i) issue management and crisis communications.7 The TA will 
allow flexibility in the course design. 
 
10.  Course design will include gathering and validation of baseline data. ADB will encourage 
innovative  course  delivery,  such  as  “blended  learning”  that  may  consist  of  instructor-led 
presentation, individual e-learning, and group work to stimulate active and engaged learners. 
 
11.  ADB will collaborate with private sector, academic, and communications professionals and 
organizations  to  bring  the  latest  know-how  in  communications.  Where  possible,  ADB  will 
coordinate with the ADB Institute to deliver these capacity building activities. The TA is envisioned 
to  further  strengthen  ADB’s  value  proposition  as  a  knowledge  provider,  particularly  in 
communications. 
 
12.  Output 2: Network of developing member country communications professionals 
established. The TA will provide opportunities for knowledge and experience sharing among 
government officials in their communications functions, and, as appropriate, with DMC journalists 
and international and regional media, through at least three subregional forums and one regional 
forum. 
 
13.  The  forums  will  enable  DMC  officials,  including  participants  at  national  seminars, 
workshops, and training, to interact with counterparts from other DMCs, international experts, 
learning institutions and/or organizations, and ADB staff to understand a range of perspectives 
and approaches to managing strategic communications in different contexts. The design of the 
TA will include lessons learned from ADB’s extensive experience in regional cooperation and 
integration. Materials presented at the subregional and regional forums will be captured and 
disseminated widely through ADB and partner channels such as Asian Development Blog, 
Development Asia and ADB Institute. The TA will identify the participants’ preferred networking 
channels  and  will  support  a  simple,  cost-effective  digital  networking  solution  to  extend 
interactions, thereby enabling a community of communications professionals. Participation and 
support of private sector groups and philanthropic organizations will contribute to sustaining a 
network of communications professionals.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $975,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF)—comprising $775,000 from TASF-6 and $200,000 
from TASF-Other Sources.8 The key expenditures are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA through the Department of Communications, which will develop 
and implement the TA in consultation with operations and knowledge departments, ADB Institute, 
and resident missions, particularly in (a) selecting pilot DMCs; (b) coordinating local TA activities;

16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and 
staff instructions.10 The TA will be implemented through an international consulting firm, individual 
consultants, and resource persons. Using quality and cost-based selection, ADB will recruit a 
consulting firm with expertise in designing and delivering communications training. ADB will hire 
an individual international consultant to advise the Department of Communications by reviewing 
the course design to ensure quality training and by evaluating the feedback to measure impact. 
In addition, ADB will hire a national consultant to provide logistics and administration support. 
They will all be part of one consultant team, which will be led by a representative from the firm 
under the supervision of ADB staff. Where possible, ADB will consider output-based contracts 
and/or lump-sum cost provision for out-of-pocket expenses for administrative efficiency. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $975,000 on a grant basis for 
Enhancing Communications Skills and Capacity of Developing Member Countries in Asia and the 
Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
9  Selection of pilot DMCs will take into consideration (i) regional representation, (ii) interest and readiness of concerned 
agencies to adopt modern communications approaches, and (iii) allow participants to attend and complete a 
progressive training course. Subregional and regional forums will offer the opportunity for cross-regional learning 
among participating DMC officials. Indicative selection criteria: (i) mid- to senior-level DMC officials and (ii) officials 
who lead or support communications in planning and/or finance ministries or their subagencies. No-objection letters 
will be obtained from DMCs prior to implementation of activities in those countries.
